value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">26</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">solitary writer with his mind fixed upon the reader in the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great room. If we could measure the 
            <choice>
              <sic>e ec</sic>
              <corr>effect</corr>
            </choice> of the audience</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">upon the play we should have a hold which is denied us</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">upon the play itself. But the audience, drawn though it is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by an 
            <choice>
              <sic>irrestible</sic>
              <corr>irresistible</corr>
            </choice> attraction to the play, is silent.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">That 
            <choice>
              <sic>sielnce</sic>
              <corr>silence</corr>
            </choice> is one of the deep gulfs that lies between us</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the play. They come 
            <choice>
              <sic>crodwing</sic>
              <corr>crowding</corr>
            </choice> across the river daily;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">but they nxmxmxx sit there silent. They neither 
            <choice>
              <sic>priasise</sic>
              <corr>praise</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nor blame. We can compare this 
            <choice>
              <sic>siel ce</sic>
              <corr>silence</corr>
            </choice> with our own d</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">silence at the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-balle" key="Ballet Russes">
            <choice>
              <sic>uddian</sic>
              <corr>Russian</corr>
            </choice></rs> or at the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-cine" key="Cinema">cinema</rs> in their</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">early days. A new art comes upon us so surprisingly</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that we sit silent, 
            <choice>
              <sic>recongsing</sic>
              <corr>recognising</corr>
            </choice> before we take the measure.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">And</del> <add place="above" hand="ms">But</add>, while we have a measuring rod, <add place="above">beauty, on our part</add> thexmxmxmxmxmxm</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a press that at once applies a standard, the Elizabethans</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">had no literature behind them to with which to compare the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">play, and no press to give it speech. To the 
            <choice>
              <sic>Elizabeathsn</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethans</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the expressive power of words after their 
            <choice>
              <sic>lo g</sic>
              <corr>long</corr>
            </choice> inadequacy</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">must have been overwhelming. Silence must have kept them</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">silent. There at the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-glob" key="Globe, The">Globe</rs> or at the <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-rose" key="Rose, The">
            <choice>
              <sic> ose</sic>
              <corr>Rose</corr>
            </choice></rs> men and women whose</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">only reading had been the Bible or some old 
            <choice>
              <sic>chornicle</sic>
              <corr>chronicle</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">came out into the light of the present moment. They saw</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>themsleves</sic>
              <corr>themselves</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>sple didly</sic>
              <corr>splendidly</corr>
            </choice> dressed. They heard them selves saying</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">out loud what they had never said yet. They heard their</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">aspirations, their profanities, their ribaldries</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">spoken for them in poetry. And there was <del hand="ms">always</del> something</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">illicit in their pleasure. The preacher and the magistrate</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">were always denouncing their emotion. That too must</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">have given it intensity.</l>
